1.title: Precursor to chords: Intervals
1.point: Intervals refer to the distance between two notes. This distance affects how the two notes sound together. Intervals are said to be made of a number of half and/or whole steps.
1.explanation1: They are keys which are "right next to each other" on a piano/keyboard. Either 2 white/black keys (as shown in blue), or a white and a black key (as show in red).
1.explanation2: They are keys which are two keys apart on the keyboard. Either 2 white/black keys (as shown in blue), or a white and a black key (as show in red). Essentially, one whole step consists of two half steps.

2.title: Chords - Major and Minor Thirds
2.point: Chords are combinations of three (or more) notes with specific intervals between each note, which create a certain signature sound.
2.explanation: Chords are created from a combination of two different intervals: Minor Thirds and Major Thirds.
2.explanation1: There are 3 half steps between the two notes of a minor third. In Western music theory, the minor third is commonly associated with a "sad" sound.
2.explanation2: There are 4 half steps between the two notes of a major third. In Western music theory, the major third is commonly associated with a "happy" sound.

3.title: Chords - Major and Minor Chords
3.previousText: Back to Major and Minor Intervals
3.point: There are four different types of chords: Major, Minor, Augmented, and Diminished. We will cover major & minor chords today.
3.explanation1: They are created from a major third (in green), followed by a minor third (in purple).
3.explanation2: They are created from a minor third (in purple), followed by a major third (in green).

4.title: Quick aside: Keys
4.point1: A key is a lookup for what chords to play in a song. There are two general types of keys: Major and Minor, which are based on Major and Minor scales, respectively.
4.point2: The key defines what scale underlies the song. The first note of a key/scale is known as the "root". For example, if a song was in the key of C Major, then the "root" of the key would be C.
4.point3: So why do keys matter in our learning? The key sets the context for interpretting a chord progression. As you will see, a chord progression is essentially a sequence of chords, and the key tells you which chords should be used.

5.title: Chord Progressions
5.point1: What are chord progressions? Chord progressions are a sequence of chords (commonly three or four chords) which define the sound of a song.
5.point2: How do we notate chord progressions? The root of the song's key is notated with the roman numeral for 1 (I), and this follows for all other notes (VII, or 7, notating the "last" note in the key's corresponding scale). A lowercase number is used if the chord is minor, and an uppercase is used if the chord is major. For example, if the song is in the key of C major, in which the notes of the corresponding C major scale are in the order of C D E F G A B, a C chord would be notated with I, a D chord with II, an E chord with III, and so on.
5.point3: In sum, the key specifies which notes correspond to, and a chord progression specifies a sequence in which a subset of those chords should be played.
